title: Probate - Start page
paragraph1: Use this service to apply for probate (also known as a ‘grant of probate’ or a ‘grant of representation’) in England and Wales.
paragraph2: Probate gives you the legal right to deal with a person’s property, money and possessions (their ‘estate’) after they’ve died.
otherServices: There are different applications in Scotland and Northern Ireland.
paragraph3: Fill in the application online, then send the will and death certificate to the probate registry by post.
paragraph4: Your progress will be saved so you can leave and return to your application.
paragraph5: You can only make an online application for probate if you have:
checklist-item1: the original will of the person who died
checklist-item2: a death certificate (this must be the original or a certified copy)
checklist-item4: been named as an executor on the will, or an update to the will (‘codicil’)
checklist-item5: spoken to all the executors who are applying for probate, and told them you’re making this application
checklist-item6: the mobile number and email of every executor who’s applying for probate, so that they can confirm that the information you provide is correct
paragraph6: The person who died must also have regarded England or Wales as their permanent home (they were ‘domiciled’ here).
paragraph7: It costs £215 to apply for probate if the value of the estate is £5,000 or more. It’s free if the value is under £5,000. Extra copies of the grant of probate cost 50p each.
paragraph8: You’ll need to pay online by debit or credit card.
